about.title: About
body: I am a Class of 2017 Course 6-3 (computer science!) major who occasionally makes things. I like speakers, all things web, computer vision, and questionably smart choices.

contact.title: Contact
body: Have a burning desire to talk to me? Now you can!

articles.title: Sublime Text Web-Development Workflow Tools
articles.description: A (currently coagulating) cespool of nice sounding workflow tools.
detailed: Imagine that if when you Control-click a sublime file, the ones related to it open. I picture this being useful for things like Backbone.js, where you have models, views, styles, templates, etc all for related components. If when I clicked on a UI element's model, all of it's related files opened up, that would be awesome. There's probably already something similar to this, so I need to spend a bit of time searching.

articles.title: Phantom.js snapshot ascii rendering + Sublime
articles.description: Sublime Text as a web browser
detailed: Basically, think sublime plugin that wraps a Phantom.js instance. When things change, a snapshot is taken of the rendered HTML, which is then rasterized into colored ascii. This ascii gets saved to a file, and that file gets opened/reloaded in a Sublime Text window.
While this alone would be cool to see, I bet this could be made into a sort of UI for other Sublime Plugins that need GUI interfaces. Would make for an interesting weekend project. Hmmmm....

articles.title: Sublime Text Plugin + Google MobWrite - in progress
articles.description: Like Google Docs, but with Sublime Text.
detailed: I've wanted to do something with some sort of collaborative edit algorithm for a while now, and I've finally gotten around to doing it. I settled on Google MobWrite because it looks like one of the most powerful options on the market. I originally thought Share.js, but the support for that project, frankly, sucks, so it's not too enticing from that aspect and the code itself doesn't seem quite as thought out as MobWrite.

Unfortunately, MobWrite doesn't have a Python client library, so I've had to start this whole processing by porting code from the Java and Javascript client stuff. Documentation is a bit lacking, so it's been slow going with lots of ? moments, but this process is almost done. Once I finish it, I will just have to write a bit of UI stuff to let users decide what parts of their code they want to share, and the code to make that acutally work.

articles.title: Desktop Speakers
articles.description: Alpair 7.3 Fullrange Driver + Folded Tabaq
detailed:
I recently got sick of not building speakers, so I decided to have another go at it and make my desk a nice setup. I wanted something that was small(ish), could work without a subwoofer, and wasn't too expensive. I've always wanted to use the venerable Mark Audio Alpair 7.3; considering their price and reputation for making good bass I decided that it was time.

I've made this specific cabinet design before, so I immediately thought of pairing it with the Alpairs. Shout out and many thanks to Bjørn Johannesen! A small amount of internet sleuthing later I convinced myself that that was the right choice, and modeled it in SolidWorks. Turns out waterjetting MDF is NOT such a great idea...

detailed: Keith asked me to make this website in anticipation of his wedding. I had a bit of fun with it and this was the result...

articles.title: Mikey's Run
articles.description: A fundraiser to support those affected by the Boston Marathon bombing.
detailed: In response to the events of the 2013 Boston Marathon, Harris Stolzenberg and I created Mikey's Run - a fundraiser to support the victims, inspired Harris's brother Mikey, a quadruple amputee and athlete. Thousands of contributors from around the world funded our campaign and sponsored Harris in the 2014 Marathon. All in all, we raised around $230,000 (including 100K from Oprah) which went directly to the Scott Rigsby Foundation to fund long term rehabilitation costs.

articles.title: Football Stadium Sound System
articles.description: Senior project gone horribly awesome

articles.title: The Aikos
articles.description: Very spiffy Fostex Horns, currently living in California.
detailed: Hands down my favorite pair of speakers I've built so far. They sound just as good as they look.

The drivers are FE108E-Sigma's modified by Planet-10 and purchased used (off of the Dave himself). The enclosures are back loaded horns called Aikos from the Spawn family of designs.

I used patinated copper veneer for the baffle and zebrawood veneer covers the front, top, and back. The sides are about 8 coats of high gloss black paint, sanded from low to high grit between every coat and then buffed.

These speakers are paired with the Sofa Subwoofer for earth-shattering bass.

articles.title: Sofa Subwoofer
articles.description: You see Ivan, when subwoofer in couch, you never run out of wubs.
detailed: One of my favorite builds. A truly massive negatively-tapered horn hidden in a couch. This was the "yolo, let's build a massive horn" high school project designed for nothing less than massive wubs and sub-20hz bass.
This sub uses two push-pull Dayton 'Classic Woofers,' in a purpose designed horn. For more info, see my thread on diyaudio.com.

articles.title: Vinyl Line Arrays
articles.description: My first ever speakers!
detailed: Imperfect but lovable line arrays that was my first real build. The woofers are Tang Band something-er-others that were once upon a time on Parts-Express buyout. These things go loud! They performed admirably as the main sound system at an outdoor dance party (with some help from a MASSIVE Brahm Exodus Anarchy-powered sealed subwoofer).

articles.title: LED Blinder 1.0
articles.description: An early foray
detailed: I made this sophomore year of high school so that I could have the coolest room lighting system on the block. While fairly unreliable, it proved to be a somewhat successful project. It was the inspiration behind the Processing Beat Detection algorithm which is actually running on the laptop on the wall in this video.

articles.title: Processing Beat Detection
articles.description: A relatively early attempt at signal analysis
detailed:
The 2.0 version of the algorithm. It is a predictive algorithm that monitors many frequency bands at the same time for "local beats" and then combines all of that information to detect "global beats."

This version of the code (above) was used by Frog Design at the 2013 SxSW kickoff party.

Interested? Check out the source code on Github.
The earlier iteration of the algorithm. Basically just an implementation of the Minim audio analysis library.

articles.title: Twitter Mining
articles.description: Moderately derpy, somewhat entertaining class project
articles.detailed: This heroku app finds the most common words on twitter and plots them by position on the map. The code for this is a bit hacky, but it's entertaining to watch.
